newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore key share index ends down, others up.
newsitem.headline: Singapore key share index ends down, others up.

text.p: The key Singapore share index ended lower on Wednesday despite rises in indices tracking blue chips, second line stocks and the Malaysian over-the-counter stocks.

"The recovery in blue chips is sustainable for longer term play. Look at the way the market stood firm despite the shocks of a war," said an institutional broker referring to U.S. missile attacks on Iraqi defence sites this week.
"The worst had been factored into the price so a rebound is expected. But a full recovery is not due till 1997," he said.
The key Straits Times Industrials Index ended down 10.78 points at 2,094.48.
The UOB Blue Chip index was up 0.68 points up at 914.52 and UOB OTC index, tracking mainly Malaysian stocks, was 8.08 points higher at 1,164.76.
The UOB SESDAQ index tracking second liners posted the biggest gain, up 1.09 percent, or 0.86 points, at 79.43.
Shares in Berger International rose 8.92 percent on market speculation that a third party was interested in taking over Berger.
The share was pushed to a new year high of S$1.71, up S$0.14. Ariza Holdings made an unconditional bid for Berger at S$1.50 on August 19.
